title: On 30 March 2018, how many GitHub forks will Baidu's Apollo autonomous driving software have?
preds: 2056, well that blows my final number guess out of the water. Should have gone risky with my original gut instinct of a random number between 2065-2070 rather than 2058.  Oh well if it blows over 2080 it'll probably be due to recent publicity.

So let's predict the final number since it's now over 2001. Between 2050-2080, so 2058 is my guess.  At 2034 now with 4 days to go. 
This might raise awareness and maybe forks http://www.zdnet.com/article/baidu-obtains-plates-to-test-autonomous-cars-on-public-roads-in-beijing/

On November 18 I said: "I'll stick my neck out and forecast we'll hit 1,750 on January 27, 2018, and we'll hit 2,000 on March 23, 2018. "  We hit 1750 on January 17, and it now appears we should hit 2,000 by March 23, probably around the 21st. I'm finding it really helps to make these micro-forecasts as a counter-action against anchor bias, as well as forcing me to think harder about the question and make concrete forecasts.  Plus, it just makes these long duration questions more fun.  We've got a small group doing this monthly on the Chevy Bolt question and it results in better forecasts. (Anyone is welcome to join in.) I highly recommend it to everyone.

The pace has been consistent enough to provide padding even in the case of a slowdown for the rest of month. But my initial forecasts gave this outcome the biggest chance, so I could be overconfident in wanting it to land there.
An average of two a day will put this number over 2k, and they've been chugging along at a slightly higher rate than that for a while.  Might still be close, though.

The recent fork-rate picked up again, and (dare I say it) regressed to the mean of about 4.7 forks / day.  To find out what the rate has been since the start of the question, I have trawled through all the forecasts on the website and picked out dated values of the number of forks. All the values are in the spread-sheet found here : https://www.dropbox.com/s/97z7753uyphfrre/Classeur.xlsx?dl=0 Thanks to all this data, I realized I had been basing my forecasts on a non-representative sub-sample of the data (only those available since I joined GJO). I have now fixed my forecast to take into account all the data in the spreadsheet. BUT
The local trend over the next few weeks will become progressively more important than the base-rate, so I'll have to keep on top of the numbers daily from here on in...
1884 on 22 February. Only 1.9 per day for past 10 days.

We currently need to average 3.36 forks/day to get to 2,001.  The 7 day average hasn't been that high since Feb. 8.  (It's currently 1.71, and it hasn't been that low since late September) I'm afraid I've gone from being a bull to a bear on this one. While the question is far from resolved, I'd say the take-away lesson for me is one of the oldest ones:  "Past performance is not an indicator of future outcomes."   'I'm right until I'm not' is no substitute for an understanding of the dynamics.

Ran the numbers again, with the rate over the past 10 days with an uncertainty of 25%. Fall squarely within the second box. Still keep 5% probability in the next box up in case something unexpected happens.
Forks are increasing slower than my slowest predicted rate. I'll revisit at the end of the week for a new update.
Number of forks decreasing - around 2/day, down from almost 7 at one point. 1874 today with 39 days to go. Looking like will fall just short of 2000. Changing forecast in light of this.
Rethinking again.  It looks like the variance of the fork rate is quite large, so it could easily revert to the mean of about 5 per day.  If it did, then we would go over 2000.

To get to 2000, we need an average of 3.4 per day.  But we are seeing a recent average of 1.86.  So it looks like we will be short of 2000 at the end of march.  (I hadn't checked the moving average before).

It's 1872 right now.  They have been averaging about 50 per week, so 2172 seems like a reasonable linear estimate.  Less than 1750 is impossible, and more than 3000 would require some unusual increase in uptake.
Currently 1872. 6 weeks to go. It’s going to be around 2000 on current trends.

Due to the continued weakness in the 7-day average (Currently only 1.86/day with 3.86 needed to hit 2,001), and the short period of time left to make up the deficit, I've taken a long look at my projection and am adjusting it accordingly.

This morning's tally : 1868. This means that over the past 6 days, there have been 12 new forks, which averages at 2 per day. There are 42 days to go to the deadline. If the average rate continues, this will lead to about 85 more forks, which stays under the 2000 limit by a respectable margin (40-50 forks). I'm switching my forecast again to account for this margin.

Hmmmm.  The 7 day growth average has dropped to 2.86, which is less than needed to get to 2,001 by the end date.  The average for the question is 4.83, and the 60 day average is 5.65.  If we revert towards the mean, we'll definitely hit 2,001.  If, however, there is an underlying reason causing potential downloaders to stop downloading forks above a 3/day average, then we won't. I don't know the answer to that, so I'm going to stick with the general rules of statistics, such as I know them, and go with exceeding 2,001.

Today's total number of forks : 1856.
Outside of new-semester related jumps in October and January, the rate measured by other forecasters is around 2.5-3.5 a day, which puts the March 30th estimates squarely on either side of the 2000 limit. For now I'll stick with the 50-50 bet between the two bins and keep a closer tally on how things evolve. I'll also keep a look out for news articles about ApolloAuto and its software, as that can generate a bump in forks.
Other consideration: the commit rate and number of lines added / deleted seems to have stabilized, indicating the coding network is also stable.

I've been tracking forks added over the 7 day periods to watch for trends, and averaged that number against total added since the inception of the question to provide balance.   Currently, the 7-Day trend is 4.57 forks/day and the total average is 4.58 forks/day.  They project a final number of 2,037 and 2,039 respectively.  Over the past couple of weeks, averaging these two numbers projects a final number of about 2,000, give or take roughly 35.   My best guess is that with Baidu's continuing push to form partnerships via the Apollo OS they will be able to maintain this rate.  Add to that the additional growth anticipated in the coming winter and spring college terms, ultimately we'll see a final number in excess of 2,000.
Baidu just had an open house for auto developers and this resulted in no appreciable change in forks:  1, 350.  Perhaps they should have invited universities.

Slightly more interest than I expected

The 7 day average for the additional number of forks continue to rise.   In addition to all the other variables, the narrow range in the 2nd option leads to an interesting statistical problem:  Once your median projection falls within 1,750 to 2,000 forks, there is little room for error. The range is so narrow that your forecast probabilities  may actually be higher in the below  1,750 and in the 2,001 - 3,000.   So if your best guess was, say, 1900 forks by March 30, your forecast could conceivably look like this: Less than 1,750:    25%
1,750 - 2,000:         20%
2,001 - 3,000:         40%
More than 3,000:  15% In effect, you're betting against your own best guess because of the relative narrowness of the 1750 - 2000 range.  Probably not news to anyone familiar with statistics, but it was a bit of a revelation to me. If the daily growth rate continues, it will be interesting to see how rapidly the consensus will shift from below 2,000 to above 2,000.
Thank you, @WhatCouldHappen, for sharing your data, analysis from GitHub at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/594631

The 7 day average has increased from 1.57 forks/day on Oct. 7, to 2.71 forks/day today.  With 166 days left, we're getting closer to a 50/50 chance at 1750.  If the academic model is still predictive, you can add another 200 forks to that, meaning you're at a best guess of 1,950.
Shifting lower as there are only 1,280 as of today.

As of October 10, 2017: 1,272 forks
- the greatest amount of interest in Baidu Apollo coincided with the Apollo 1.0.0 release
https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?q=baidu%20apollo
- contributors must fork the repository to contribute changes to the master branch 
- the number of GitHub commits has steadily declined since release:
https://github.com/ApolloAuto/apollo/graphs/contributors?from=2017-07-02&to=2017-10-09&type=c
- assumptions: 
1) most forks are done by programmers who intend to contribute as opposed to observers (fork vs watch features on GitHub)
2) active contributors do not need to fork a large project very often
- unless they are contributing to a fast-changing section of the project, contributors are less likely to need new forks (can develop independently for longer periods with older forks)
3) if the number of GitHub commits per time period are declining, then the number of new forks over the same time period are also declining. Without major updates to Baidu Apollo, the contributor community, and thus number of forks, is unlikely to grow much larger in size.
1272 now, about 60 per 2 last weeks, 30 per week.

From Sept 25 thru Saturday, the 7 day average of forks added per day dropped from 10.86/day to 1.57/day.  However, starting yesterday, the average has started to rise again due to increased activity, now at 2.14/day as of this morning.   With 172 days to go, if this is a trend, then I'm a little low in my predictions.  Starting to shift my forecast to reflect possible unexpected trend.
1271 forks as of 9 October. 130 added in past 3 weeks. At that rate, there would be approximately 2,335 forks by the end of the question period. I'm just not sure that interest will be maintained.
Seeing a small uptick the last couple of days.  Watching to see if it's a blip, or a trend.

The rate I've inferred seems higher than what some have mentioned, and should be able to hit 1750. The range 1750-2000 is smaller and isn't as difficult to surpass if this project gets periodic bursts of interest on top of small steady interest.
Shifting lower and will continue to do so unless something big changes.

It appears, for the moment, the academic model proposed by @amory10 is predictive.  There was a bump of about 100 forks during the last two weeks of Sept.  Other than that, the average is 1/day.  If you forecast 2 more 100 fork bumps (Winter and Spring terms) plus 1 fork per day, you're looking at 1636 by March 30.   Differing opinions always encouraged and welcome.
Following @fifty-sixty on the basis of excellent data from Github and analysis of the base rate that has been developing so far. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/581788

Interest would need to precipitously drop to land in either of the first two ranges. Will adjust down if things seem to slow a lot in the next week or two, but still expect it to get above 1750.

1140 forks at the time of this forecast.
Following @dada, excellent new data and analysis at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/568232.
Autonomous cars not popular enough, Baidu centered in China and therefore non-Chinese fearful of submitting code/traceable information, and initial enthusiasm gone.

Low forecast because I do not believe initial impetus will be sustained either by a community effort (programming autonomous vehicles is hard) or by the company fostering a community. Many ways to follow this over this long time period, follow @BaiduResearch on Twitter, see how much documentation is produced, events, etc. Also forks can be followed using the fork-stats project  https://github.com/arimbr/fork-stats What I see now is a lot of curiosity and very little community. Few commits, branches, contributors, documentation. Projects are forked for a lot of reasons, but they continue to be forked because a healthy dynamic is created.
One reason people fork projects is by accident: they click on the fork button instead of the number when they only want to see the stats:
https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/200663/why-do-people-fork-repositories-on-github

I think that there was probably a burst of initial enthusiasm that probably drove up the number of forks. However, because Apollo is already one third of the way to 3,000 and we have still have six months to go I think we get slow growth over time.

Starting rather flat. It is an interesting topic and I'd expect it to get some traction in the coming month. 2-3k forks is a lot and it strongly depends on the "long tail" of hardly contributing people. I.e. if even a handful of universities use it in a course this winter term this could add a thousand forks or only a handful, depending on how they organise it. We'll have to see how it looks in November

3,000+ forks is quite a lot, unlikely there will be so many people wishing to "modify it, and suggest changes" in given timeframe, but as forking is often used instead of cloning to have a local copy, students and just curious minds can drive the number up. Especially as they already have 1,107 in just 2 months. For comparison - most real and heavy developments like programming languages (PHP, Ruby, ...) seems to have 1,000-10,000 forks. I think @amory10 made a good point (below) - result might depend on academic participation.

My thinking is that the outcome to this question will be determined by participation -- or lack thereof -- in academia.  If you look at some of the most forked repositories, a few of them are required for coursework on places like Coursera.  Baidu has said it wants to partner with universities, and if that happens it could really move the needle.   But without lots of academic participation, I don't see this number moving too dramatically.  Thoughts??
